metadata.case_name: K. D. Kamath and Company v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore

facts.text: The appellant is a firm consisting of six partners constituted under the deed dated March 20, 1959 marked Ex. A.
The business of the partnership is stated to have been carried on in partnership from October 1, 1958.
The partnership was registered under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932 on or about August 11, 1959.
For assessment year 1959-60, corresponding to previous year ending March 31, 1959, appellant filed application under s.26A to ITO for registration.
ITO by order dated September 28, 1960 declined registration holding no genuine partnership created by deed, business is sole concern of K.D. Kamath, relying on clauses 8,9,12,16.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner on May 5, 1961 confirmed ITO order, emphasizing clause 12.

Income-tax Appellate Tribunal allowed assessee's appeal, held deed satisfies agreement to share profits/losses and agency, directed registration, relied on Balubhai Gulabdas Navlakhi v. CIT and distinguished Umarbhai Chandbhai v. CIT.
Revenue applied under s.66(1) on October 4, 1962 for reference; Tribunal referred question: Whether on facts, firm could be granted registration under s.26A for 1959-60.
Mysore High Court by judgment dated January 21, 1964 in I.T.R.C. No.13/1963 answered against assessee, held no agency due to control with K.D. Kamath per clauses 5-9,12,16.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.
Parties to deed: 1. Shri Krishnarao Dadasaheb Kamat (principal financing managing partner), 2-6 working partners contributing labour.
Profits/losses shared: K.D. Kamath 5/15, others 2/15 each.
Revenue not challenging genuineness of document, but no legal partnership relation inter se.

legal_issues.text: Whether the deed dated March 20, 1959 (Ex. A) is an instrument of partnership on the basis of which the appellant firm is eligible for registration under s.26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, i.e., whether it creates relationship of partners inter se satisfying agreement to share profits/losses and agency.

petitioner_arguments.text: Partnership deed read as whole shows agreement to share profits/losses; control with K.D. Kamath does not negate agency or partnership.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Partnership Act s.4; various High Court and SC decisions

petitioner_arguments.text: Conditions for s.26A registration satisfied: genuine instrument specifying shares, valid partnership exists.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: IT Act s.26A; Agarwal & Co. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: No legal relationship of partners inter se; no agency as management/control entirely with K.D. Kamath, others cannot act independently (clauses 8,9,12,16).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Partnership Act s.4, s.18; Umarbhai Chandbhai v. CIT; M.P. Davis v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Restrictions on borrowing/pledging negate implied authority/agency.

court_reasoning.text: Deed converts proprietary concern to partnership; clauses show sharing of profits/losses (cl.5), mutual rights/duties (cl.13-16), satisfies first essential of s.4 Partnership Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proprietary concern vanished; agreement to share profits/losses amply satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: Control/management with K.D. Kamath (cl.7,8) not destructive of partnership; he acts for all; restrictions inter se valid under s.11,20 Partnership Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Business carried on by K.D. Kamath acting for all; agency implicit and satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes M.P. Davis and Umarbhai as extreme cases lacking essentials; follows Steel Brothers, Balubhai, etc.; conditions of s.26A fulfilled.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere control in one partner, bank operation, borrowing restrictions do not negate partnership if essentials present.

holdings.text: Deed dated March 20, 1959 creates valid partnership under s.4 Partnership Act satisfying sharing profits/losses and agency; eligible for registration under s.26A IT Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balubhai Gulabdas Navlakhi v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide control in one partner does not negate partnership if essentials satisfied.

precedents_cited.case_name: Umarbhai Chandbhai v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Extreme case where father retained proprietary control; essentials absent.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. P. Davis v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Extreme master-servant cloak; not applicable as essentials present here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Steel Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Management/control in one not destructive of partnership.

precedents_cited.case_name: Agarwal and Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Conditions for mandatory registration under s.26A.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. A. Abdul Rahim & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Genuine valid partnership must be registered if s.26A complied.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pathrose Rice Oil Mills (CIT Kerala v.)
precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions on bank/borrowing not negate partnership.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.A.C. Ratnaswamy Nadar Sons v. CIT Madras

precedents_cited.relevance: Control in few partners, no capital from one, still partnership.

precedents_cited.case_name: City Tobacco Mart v. CIT Mysore

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of firms; definitions from Partnership Act; reference to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of partnership; real relation from facts; mutual rights/duties by contract; agency; implied authority restrictions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, answered the referred question in affirmative in favour of assessee, set aside High Court order, held firm eligible for registration under s.26A for 1959-60.

key_quotes.text: "Partnership is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.4 Partnership Act defining essentials.

key_quotes.text: "The mere fact that more control is to be exercised only by one of the partners, is not a circumstance which militates against the parties having entered into a partnership arrangement as understood in law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding rejecting High Court view on control.

key_quotes.text: "Two essential conditions to be satisfied are (1) that there should be an agreement to share the profits as well as the losses of the business, and (2) the business must be carried on by all or any of them acting for all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
